comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1:

User not approved, see admin, no CI
Uploaded patch set 2.

Patch Set 2:

User not approved, see admin, no CI

Patch Set 2:

Hi Brad 

Please help review this merge request.

Thanks

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(18 comments)

I stopped reviewing at this point.

I suggest reading through https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/meta-layer-guidelines.md

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

+1 to Patricks comment.

To the authors, please read and understand the expectations for these layers.

Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the review. Will rework on it and submit a new merge request. 
Can we abandon this one?

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> Thanks for the review. Will rework on it and submit a new merge request. 
> Can we abandon this one?

If you're simply going to update this change with fixes there is no reason to abandon.  Keep the change (and same change id) and contribute fixes to this same commit.  Gerrit will create a new revision for you as long as the change-id matches.

Alternatively, and this is probably what I would suggest, you could break this commit up into smaller pieces.  Create a simple commit that just adds the basics of a machine, without any of your specific customization, would be much easier to review than a 50k line commit all at once.

Doing pieces at a time is certainly how we prefer code to be delivered rather than gigantic commits.

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> > Patch Set 2:
> > 
> > Thanks for the review. Will rework on it and submit a new merge request. 
> > Can we abandon this one?
> 
> If you're simply going to update this change with fixes there is no reason to abandon.  Keep the change (and same change id) and contribute fixes to this same commit.  Gerrit will create a new revision for you as long as the change-id matches.
> 
> Alternatively, and this is probably what I would suggest, you could break this commit up into smaller pieces.  Create a simple commit that just adds the basics of a machine, without any of your specific customization, would be much easier to review than a 50k line commit all at once.
> 
> Doing pieces at a time is certainly how we prefer code to be delivered rather than gigantic commits.

Yes, will break this commit into smaller commits. Will start with adding the basics of machine first. That's the reason I was for requesting to abandon this one.

Patch Set 2:

> Yes, will break this commit into smaller commits. Will start with adding the basics of machine first. That's the reason I was for requesting to abandon this one.

Sure, go ahead.  Where we don’t want to abandon is if later on you’re going to submit something very similar.

Abandoned

Too large commit. Will submit it in smaller commits. Also, address these review comments in new commits.
Please fix the commit message to only have one Change-Id / S-o-b.
Why are you even using pyphosphor anymore?  No new systems should be using this.
Can you use a systemd timer for this instead?  See meta-facebook/meta-tiogapass/recipes-extended/rsyslog/rsyslog/rotate-event-logs.service
This whole commit needs to be updated to the new Yocto override syntax.  I think you'll find it doesn't even build with the latest code.
Why is gobject-introspection being used?
We should not be pointing at any Intel-BMC repositories.  If this code is useful for the x86 architecture, can you ask Intel to contribute it as a recipe on their own?

You absolutely may not copy existing recipes to hack like this.  This recipe already exists in meta-intel:

./meta-intel-openbmc/meta-common/recipes-intel/ipmi/intel-ipmi-oem_git.bb
Please don't patch their code.  Contribute these as changes.
We should not be pointing to this.
Why?  We shouldn't even have C code.
We do not allow code in the openbmc/openbmc repository.
We do not allow patching the kernel like this.  Please get this support into the upstream tree.

I'm not going to review any of this C code.  We don't allow checking code into openbmc/openbmc.  Any code like this you're wholesale copying from facebook/openbmc probably needs significant rework to make it acceptable to openbmc/openbmc's design principles.
Please contribute these to entity-manager directly.
This repository should no longer be used.
Please don't patch these.  Contribute them as needed to the upstream repositories.
No code in this repository.
Contribute rather than patch.
